facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1865 of 1967

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1865 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment Decree dated the 19th October, 1965 of the Patna High Court in Original Decree No.311 of 1960

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment Decree dated the 19th October, 1965 of the Patna High Court in Original Decree No311 of 1960.

facts.text: Mining lease granted by the 1st respondent but alleged to have been done so in the name of the 1st respondent by the 2nd respondent in favour of Haricharan Singh J.D. Co. on 7-9-1950

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is against the judgment of the Patna High Court by Special Leave granted by this Court. It arises out of a mining lease granted by the 1st respondent but alleged to have been ,done so in the name of the 1st respondent by the 2nd respondent in favour of Haricharan Singh J.D. Co. on 7-9-1950.

facts.text: In pursuance of the lease a sum of Rs. 80,000/- was paid to the 1st respondent

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the lease a sum of Rs. 80,000/- was paid to the 1st respondent.

facts.text: The plaint allegation was that the 1st respondent was a Limited Company created by the 2nd respondent

anchor.surface_text: The plaint allegation was that the 1st respondent was a Limited Company created by the 2nd respondent.

facts.text: There was an earlier lease in respect of the same property in favour of respondents 3 and 4 which expired on 4-4-1950

anchor.surface_text: There was an earlier lease in respect of the same property in favour of respondents 3 and 4 which expired on 4-4-1950.

facts.text: Haricharan Singh J.D. Co. later changed its name to Kuju Collieries Ltd. who are the appellants

anchor.surface_text: Haricharan Singh J.D. Co. later changed its name to Kuju Collieries Ltd. who are the appellants.

facts.text: As the plaintiff did number get the possession of the leased property it instituted a suit for recovery of possession of the leased property along with mesne profits and in the alternative for refund of the sum of Rs. 80,000/- and certain other sums

anchor.surface_text: As the plaintiff did number get the possession of the leased property it instituted a suit for recovery of possession of the leased property along with mesne profits and in the alternative for refund of the sum of Rs. 80,000/- and certain other sums.

facts.text: The present appeal is companycerned only with that amount

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is, however, companycerned only with that amount.

facts.text: In the suit the 1st respondent and the 2nd respondent took the stand that the 1st respondent was number created by the 2nd respondent, that the lease was by the 1st respondent and the amount was paid to the 1st respondent alone and number to the 2nd respondent

facts.text: The 1st respondent also companytended that the leased properties were handed over to the plaintiff, that they were number aware that respondents 3 and 4 were resisting the plaintiffs claim and that the 1st respondent was number in any case responsible therefor

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent also companytended that the leased properties were handed over to the plaintiff, that they were number aware that respondents 3 and 4 were resisting the plaintiffs claim and that the 1st respondent was number in any case responsible therefor and that therefore the plaintiff was number entitled to any relief.

facts.text: During the pendency of this appeal respondents 2 and 3 died and their legal representatives have number been brought on record

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this appeal respondents 2 and 3 died and their legal representatives have number been brought on record.

facts.text: The appellant is number claiming any relief against any of the other respondents except respondent No. 1

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is number claiming any relief against any of the other respondents except respondent No. 1 and it is, therefore, unnecessary to refer to the attitude taken by them in the suit.

facts.text: After the institution of the suit the Bihar Land Reforms Act came into force as a result of which any lessee working a mine became direct lessee under the State, and as the plaintiff was number working the mines any claim in respect of the possession of the mines became unenforceable

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary at this stage to mention that after the institution of the suit the Bihar Land Reforms Act came into force as a result of which any lessee working a mine became direct lessee under the State, and ,as the plaintiff was number working the mines any claim in respect of the possession of the mines became unenforceable.

facts.text: The appellant has, therefore, companyfined his claim to the sum of Rs. 80,000/- as payable to it by the 1st respondent

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has, therefore, companyfined his claim to the sum of Rs. 80,000/- as payable to it by the 1st respondent.

facts.text: The Trial Court held that ... the plaintiff was number entitled to claim relief under s. 65 of the Indian Contract Act. It, therefore, dismissed the suit

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court held that as the pailntiff was already in the business of mining and had the advantage of companysulting its lawyers and solicitors and their lease deed was drawn up and prepared by solicitors, there was numberoccasion for the plaintiff to have been under any kind of ignorance of law and as the Mineral Concession Rules of 1949 rendered any stipulation for payment of salami illegal and the lease on that basis was also illegal, the plaintiff was number entitled to claim relief under s. 65 of the Indian Contract Act. It, therefore, dismissed the suit.

issues.text: Whether s. 65 of the Contract Act applies to the facts of the case

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff on the facts and circumstances of this case. Section 65. reads as follows When an agreement is discovered to Be void, or when a contract becomes void, any person who has received any advantage under such agreement or contract is bound to restore it, or to make compensation for it to the person from whom he received it.

issues.text: Whether the contract was either discovered to be void or became void subsequently

anchor.surface_text: Therefore. clearly the lease in favour of the plaintiff was contrary to the provisions of the Mines and Minerals Regulation Development Act 1948 and the Mineral Rules 1949 and as such void. The further question is whether it could be said that this contract was either discovered to be void or became void.

issues.text: Whether s. 70 or s. 72 of the Contract Act applies to the facts of the case

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it a case to which s. 70 or s. 72 of the Contract Act applies. The payment of the money was not made lawfully, nor was it done under a mistake or under coercion.

anchor.surface_text: Nor could it be said that the agreement was discovered to be void after it was entered into. As pointed out by the Trial Court the plaintiff was already in the business of mining and had the advantage of consulting its lawyers and solicitors.

arguments.claim: s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff on the facts and circumstances of this case. Section 65. reads as follows When an agreement is discovered to Be void,

arguments.claim: Section 65 makes a distinction between an agreement discovered to be void and a contract becoming void

anchor.surface_text: The section makes a distinction between an agreement and a contract. According to s. 2 of the Contract Act an agreement which is enforceable by law is a contract and an agreement which is not enforceable by law is said to be void. Therefore, when the earlier part of the section speaks of an agreement being discovered to be void it means that the agreement is not enforceable and is, therefore, not a contract. It means that it was void. It may- be that the parties or one of the parties to the agreement may not have, when they entered into the agreement, known that the agreement was in law not enforceable. They might have come to know later that the agreement was not enforceable. The second part of the section refers to a contract becoming void. That refers to a case where an agreement which was originally enforceable and was, therefore, a contract, becomes void due to subsequent happenings.

arguments.claim: where parties knew agreement unlawful and void at time of entering, s.65 does not apply as not discovered subsequently nor became void later

anchor.surface_text: But where even at the time when the agreement is entered into both the parties knew that it was not lawful and, therefore, void, there was no contract but only an agreement and it is not a case where it is discovered to be void subsequently. Nor is it a case Of the contract becoming void due to subsequent happenings. Therefore, s. 65 of the Contract Act did not apply.

arguments.claim: Privy Council interpretation of s.65 supports distinction and application to ab initio void agreements discovered later

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council in its decision in Harnath Kaur v. Inder Bahadur Singh (1923) 50 I.A. 69, 75-76 observed The section deals with (a) agreements and (b) contracts. The distinction between them is apparent by s. 2 by clause (c) every set of promises forming the consideration for each other is an agreement, and by clause (h) an agreement enforceable by law is a contract. Section 65, therefore, deals with (a) agreements enforceable by law and (b) with agreements not so enforceable.

arguments.claim: Hyderabad High Court Full Bench in Budhulal v. Deccan Banking Company supports that s.65 applies only if voidness discovered subsequently, not if known illegal

anchor.surface_text: A full Bench of five Judges of the Hyderabad High Court in Budhulal v. Deccan Banking Company AIR 1955 Hyd. 69 speaking through our brother, Jaganmohan Reddy J., as he then was, referred with approval to these observations of the Privy Council. They then went on to refer to the observations of Pollock and Mulla [...] In our opinion, the view of the learned authors is neither supported [...] the courts do not assist a person who comes with unclean hands.

arguments.claim: lease void under s.4 Mines and Minerals Act 1948 as granted contrary to rules

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 of the Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act. 1948 provides no mining lease shall be granted after the commencement of this Act otherwise than in accordance with the rules made under this Act. and any mining lease granted contrary to the provisions of sub-section (1) shall be void and of no effect.

arguments.claim: lease void as plaintiff had no certificate of approval under Rule 45 Mineral Concession Rules 1949

anchor.surface_text: Under Rule 45 of the Mineral Concession Rules 1949 no prospecting license or mining lease shall be granted except to a person holding certificate of approval from the Provincial Government having jurisdiction over the land in respect of which the concession is required. The plaintiff had no certificate of approval from the State Government.

arguments.claim: lease void as stipulation for premium (salami) violated Rule 49 Mineral Concession Rules 1949

anchor.surface_text: Under Rule 49 no grantor of a prospecting license or a mining lease shall charge any premium in addition to or in lieu of the prospecting fee, surface fee, surface rent, dead rent or royalty specified in such license or lease. There was a stipulation for payment of a premium under the lease deed in favour of the plaintiff.

arguments.claim: contract was void at its inception, not discovered to be void or became void subsequently

anchor.surface_text: Therefore. clearly the lease in favour of the plaintiff was contrary to the provisions of the Mines and Minerals Regulation Development Act 1948 and the Mineral Rules 1949 and as such void. The further question is whether it could be said that this contract was either discovered to be void or became void. The facts enumerated above would show that the contract was void at its inception and this is not a case where it became void subsequently.

arguments.claim: s.70 or s.72 Contract Act do not apply as payment not lawful, not by mistake or coercion

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it a case to which s. 70 or s. 72 of the Contract Act applies. The payment of the money was not made lawfully, nor was it done under a mistake or under coercion.

arguments.claim: 1st respondent not created by 2nd respondent, lease by 1st, amount paid to 1st alone

anchor.surface_text: In the suit the 1st respondent and the 2nd respondent took the stand that the 1st respondent was not created by the 2nd respondent, that the lease was by the 1st respondent and the amount was paid to the 1st respondent alone and not to the 2nd respondent.

arguments.claim: leased properties handed over, not aware of resistance by 3&4, not responsible, plaintiff not entitled to relief

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent also contended that the leased properties were handed over to the plaintiff, that they were not aware that respondents 3 and 4 were resisting the plaintiffs claim and that the 1st respondent was not in any case responsible therefor and that therefore the plaintiff was not entitled to any relief.

arguments.court_reasoning: Appeal narrowed to refund against 1st respondent only

holdings.text: s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff on the facts and circumstances of this case

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff on the facts and circumstances of this case. Section 65. reads as follows When an agreement is discovered to Be void, or when a contract becomes void, any person who has received any advantage under such agreement or contract is bound to restore it, or to make compensation for it to the person from whom he received it. The section makes a distinction between an agreement and a contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes agreements discovered to be void or contracts becoming void subsequently from cases where parties knew agreement unlawful and void ab initio at inception; follows Privy Council and High Court precedents

holdings.text: the lease in favour of the plaintiff was contrary to the provisions of the Mines and Minerals Regulation Development Act 1948 and the Mineral Rules 1949 and as such void

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 of the Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act. 1948 provides no mining lease shall be granted after the commencement of this Act otherwise than in accordance with the rules made under this Act. and any mining lease granted contrary to the provisions of sub-section (1) shall be void and of no effect. Under Rule 45 of the Mineral Concession Rules 1949 no prospecting license or mining lease shall be granted except to a person holding certificate of approval from the Provincial Government having jurisdiction over the land in respect of which the concession is required.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease granted without certificate of approval under Rule 45 and with stipulation for premium violating Rule 49, contrary to s.4 of 1948 Act

holdings.text: the contract was void at its inception and this is not a case where it became void subsequently

anchor.surface_text: Therefore. clearly the lease in favour of the plaintiff was contrary to the provisions of the Mines and Minerals Regulation Development Act 1948 and the Mineral Rules 1949 and as such void. The further question is whether it could be said that this contract was either discovered to be void or became void. The facts enumerated above would show that the contract was void at its inception and this is not a case where it became void subsequently.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules in force before lease; no prior approval or valid grant; premium illegal from start

holdings.text: Nor is it a case to which s. 70 or s. 72 of the Contract Act applies

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it a case to which s. 70 or s. 72 of the Contract Act applies. The payment of the money was not made lawfully, nor was it done under a mistake or under coercion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payment under illegal void agreement, not lawful, mistaken, or coerced

holdings.text: Nor could it be said that the agreement was discovered to be void after it was entered into

anchor.surface_text: Nor could it be said that the agreement was discovered to be void after it was entered into. As pointed out by the Trial Court the plaintiff was already in the business of mining and had the advantage of consulting its lawyers and solicitors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff in mining business, consulted lawyers, deed by solicitors; no ignorance of law

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff on the facts and circumstances of this case. Section 65. reads as follows When an agreement is discovered to Be void, or when a contract becomes void, any person who has received any advantage under such agreement or contract is bound to restore it, or to make compensation for it to the person from whom he received it. The section makes a distinction between an agreement and a contract.
We are of the view that s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff on the facts and circumstances of this case.
outside the scope of section 65. At the same time Courts will number render assistance to persons who induce innocent parties to enter into companytra

edges.explanation: Holding h2 that the lease is void under the Act supports holding h3 that the contract was void at inception.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 of the Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act. 1948 provides no mining lease shall be granted after the commencement of this Act otherwise than in accordance with the rules made under this Act. and any mining lease granted contrary to the provisions of sub-section (1) shall be void and of no effect. Under Rule 45 of the Mineral Concession Rules 1949 no prospecting license or mining lease shall be granted except to a person holding certificate of approval from the Provincial Government having jurisdiction over the land in respect of which the concession is required.
We are of the view that s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff on the facts and circumstances of this case.
t being illegal by reason of its being opposed to public policy or morality or a companytract void for other reasons. Even agreement the performance o

edges.explanation: Holding h3 that the contract was void at inception and not subsequently directly addresses issue i2 on whether the contract was discovered void or became void subsequently.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore. clearly the lease in favour of the plaintiff was contrary to the provisions of the Mines and Minerals Regulation Development Act 1948 and the Mineral Rules 1949 and as such void. The further question is whether it could be said that this contract was either discovered to be void or became void. The facts enumerated above would show that the contract was void at its inception and this is not a case where it became void subsequently.
We are of the view that s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff on the facts and circumstances of this case.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it a case to which s. 70 or s. 72 of the Contract Act applies. The payment of the money was not made lawfully, nor was it done under a mistake or under coercion.
We are of the view that s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff on the facts and circumstances of this case.
e earlier decision of the Hyderabad High Court in Budhulal v. Deccan Banking Co. Ltd.  supra . In a recent judgment of this Court in Shri Ramagya Pras

anchor.surface_text: Nor could it be said that the agreement was discovered to be void after it was entered into. As pointed out by the Trial Court the plaintiff was already in the business of mining and had the advantage of consulting its lawyers and solicitors.
We are of the view that s. 65 of the Contract Act cannot help the plaintiff on the facts and circumstances of this case.
